fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let S 	riangleright P and T 	riangleright Q be containers. We define their composite S 	riangleright P \circ T 	riangleright Q as the container \sum _{s : S} P\ s 	o T 	riangleright \lambda (s , f) . \sum _{p : P\ s} Q\ (f\ p) This composition commutes with container extension, which is to say: \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P \circ T 	riangleright Q brack 
egthinspace brack \cong \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P brack 
egthinspace brack \circ \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack T 	riangleright Q brack 
egthinspace brack

fr:title.text: Monad container composition via distributive law

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container composition via distributive law

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (S \triangleright P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleright Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers and (u_1 , u_2 , v_1 , v_2) be a monad container distributive law of type T \triangleright Q \circ S \triangleright P \Rightarrow S \triangleright P \circ T \triangleright Q.

Given a container (S 	riangleright P), it's extension is defined as the \mathbf {Set}-functor \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P brack 
egthinspace brack with action on objects \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P brack 
egthinspace brack \ A := \sum _{s : S} P\ s 	o A and action on morphisms (\lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P brack 
egthinspace brack \ f)\ (s , g) := (s , f \circ g)

The operation \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack - brack 
egthinspace brack can be extended to a functor from \mathbf {Cont} to [\mathbf {Set},\mathbf {Set}] by mapping container morphisms to natural transformations as follows \langle 
egthinspace \langle u 	riangleright v angle 
egthinspace angle _A\ (s , f) := (u\ s , f \circ v) The functor given by \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack - brack 
egthinspace brack and \langle 
egthinspace \langle - angle 
egthinspace angle is fully faithful.
